name: nytimes
text: Evening Briefing: Here's what you need to know at the end of the day  https://t.co/9tlSuzi8jW

name: nytimes
text:
March 9: NBA player Rudy Gobert decides to mock people’s fears of the coronavirus by touching all of the reporters’ microphones after a postgame news conference. 

Two days later, he tested positive for the virus. https://t.co/0wmUVA6RMd

name: nytimes
text:
March 11: The NBA becomes the first major league to suspend its season. 

No one was more shocked than Mark Cuban, owner of the Dallas Mavericks. https://t.co/bxddYO9oST

name: nytimes
text: March 12: The NCAA fell next, calling off its women’s and men’s basketball tournament. All spring college sports we… https://t.co/4FU5zmTrEx

name: nytimes
text:
April 2: The world’s elite athletes, whose schedules are meticulously planned, were left with too much free time.

Roger Federer practiced his trick shots... in a snowstorm.
https://t.co/kPN4gtb0sp

name: nytimes
text:
April 12: The WNBA and NBA stars played HORSE at home. 

It was televised to a sports-starved audience, but shaky video and audio and an absence of interesting shots meant the show got mostly bad reviews.
https://t.co/m9HUqyx5Hb

name: nytimes
text: In the middle of the sports desert, there was an unexpected feat. For the first time, a skateboarder landed a 1080, 3 full spins, on the half pipe. Oh, and he was 11 years old. https://t.co/c9sPU3636v

name: nytimes
text: June 5: After shutting down the season, the women’s soccer league in England determined its champion by points per… https://t.co/0NbOGtHtNS

name: nytimes
text:
But that's not all.

There were fake fans in the stands, quarterbacks getting haircuts and quarterbacks splitting their pants. Leagues folding and leagues starting up again. https://t.co/we1FAaFxK1

name: nytimes
text:
2 more Trump campaign staff members who attended the president’s indoor rally in Tulsa have tested positive for the coronavirus. 6 other staffers had tested positive before the event.
https://t.co/tAWrCnOmve

name: nytimes
text: RT @julianbarnes: To recruit a spy, first you must recruit mid-career professionals who binge watch The Handmaid’s Tale: https://t.co/G5FxyNANE6

name: nytimes
text:
Joe Biden’s campaign is calling an effort from the Trump campaign to add a fourth presidential debate a “distraction,” confirming instead that Biden will participate in the 3 debates that are already planned
https://t.co/8NnyaQsE6I

name: nytimes
text: The University of Michigan is said to be withdrawing from hosting a planned presidential debate in October because of concerns about the coronavirus https://t.co/HuWwZivYTv

name: nytimes
text: RT @nytimesarts: Joel Schumacher, whose movies — including  “St. Elmo’s Fire,” “The Lost Boys” and “Batman & Robin” — were cultural mile markers of the 1980s and ’90s, has died at 80 https://t.co/kMGl7Ybcb9

name: nytimes
text: A new archaeological discovery at the site of an ancient village near Stonehenge promises to offer significant clues about life more than 4,500 years ago https://t.co/vgKbe1vPwf

name: nytimes
text:
RT @reidepstein: NEWS: The University of Michigan is pulling out of the Oct 15 Trump-Biden debate and it is moving to ... Miami, per me, @jmartNYT & @ByMattStevens 

https://t.co/8SrRiOx8VK

name: nytimes
text: RT @Jan_Ransom: So what are criminal courts like in New York City right now? Here's everything you ever wanted to know and more in this story by @alanfeuer @nicole_hong @BenWeiserNYT + me: https://t.co/kLWg2BA622

name: nytimes
text: An 18-year-old Muslim woman was forced to remove her hijab for a booking photograph after she was arrested in Miami this month during a protest, an advocacy group said https://t.co/uQD7L4e95f

name: nytimes
text: Just steps from the White House in Lafayette Square, protesters threw ropes over a statue of President Andrew Jackson and tried to pull it down. Police officers with riot shields and pepper spray confronted the demonstrators. https://t.co/evmgYAtGod https://t.co/rcES1YbS04

name: nytimes
text: The Tennessean fired an advertising manager a day after the newspaper published a full-page ad from a biblical prophecy group claiming “Islam” would detonate a bomb in Nashville https://t.co/q7bDbge4Tz

name: nytimes
text: RT @nytopinion: "The pandemic has given us a glimpse of a world in which business as usual in our health care system was upended," @sjauhar writes. "Reflexively returning to the status quo may be good for our bottom line, but it won’t serve our patients well."   https://t.co/xn4Whw0o1V

name: nytimes
text: Health officials in the U.S. have been subject to harassment, personal insults and death threats in recent weeks, a response from a vocal and angry minority of the public who say that mask requirements and restrictions on businesses have gone too far https://t.co/QtFmmjtrSe

name: nytimes
text: The White House trade adviser, Peter Navarro, said on Monday night that the trade deal between the United States and China was “over,” briefly causing stock markets to dive before he and President Trump quickly walked back the remarks https://t.co/7FhqBrBIak

name: nytimes
text: RT @halbfinger: Pressure tactic vs. smokescreen: @realDonaldTrump’s divided Middle East team meets today to hash out what to do about annexation. Our analysis of the looming showdown between @jaredkushner and @USAmbIsrael David Friedman. w/@michaelcrowley https://t.co/tvAFeMbuLC

name: nytimes
text: The Trump administration announced that it was designating 4 more Chinese state-run media organizations that have operations in the U.S. as foreign missions. China will most likely retaliate. https://t.co/drft5zfRsF

name: nytimes
text:
RT @christophclarey: Undefeated in 2020 before the pandemic shut down the tour, Novak Djokovic is hardly on a winning streak anymore. His no-distancing Adria Tour looks like folly at this stage. My latest with input from many in the game:
https://t.co/WDnzRmQJaF https://t.co/fTgkro3cCm

name: nytimes
text: This is peak fruit season in Thailand, when the rising mercury concentrates the sugars in the tropical bounty that is native to Southeast Asia https://t.co/qi9sS6qo02

name: nytimes
text: Europe morning briefing: Here's what you need to know to start your day https://t.co/8VZmStb82K

name: nytimes
text: RT @SherylNYT: White Americans are having an awakening, going to protests, buying books on race, removing racist tattoos. “We’re not saying all lives don’t matter. It’s that all lives can’t matter until black lives matter.’” ⁦@amy_harmon⁩ ⁦@abscribe⁩  https://t.co/lBxg6So2yA

name: nytimes
text: The West African nation of Burkina Faso has fallen into violence and chaos. Some of the gunmen are terrorists, loosely allied with ISIS or Al Qaeda. Some are bandits. And it is seldom spoken of, but some are soldiers in the country's armed forces. https://t.co/olo4YjxlXX

name: nytimes
text: With workplaces pressing to figure out how to safely reopen, companies in tech, catering and design are rushing to sell employers on fever scanners, box lunches and tools for social distancing. But it’s too soon to tell if they will work. https://t.co/xG7oWkrus9

name: nytimes
text: RT @StevenErlanger: Betraying Frustration with China, E.U. Leaders Press for Progress on Trade Talks. The EU asks, but China is noncommittal. My take. https://t.co/LgnmcPUrVX

name: nytimes
text:
RT @iandenisjohnson: Photographer Li Zhensheng, the "Red-Color News Soldier" whose images revealed life in Mao's China, has died. Here's a 2012 Q&A with him in his home in Beijing by @chiyin_sim
published in @nytimesphoto 
(resending to correct spelling)
https://t.co/OmPqVgcMeN

name: nytimes
text: Sweden has suffered roughly twice as many infections and 5 times as many deaths as its 3 Nordic neighbors combined, leading them to close their borders to Swedes and cementing the country's status as Scandinavia’s pariah state https://t.co/nnemmcM6qO

name: nytimes
text: A former justice of Australia’s highest court sexually harassed 6 young women on his staff, a court inquiry has found, reigniting #MeToo outrage in a country where many women are still calling for a fuller reckoning https://t.co/tyyJM30XlY

name: nytimes
text: A first summit meeting between a new European Union leadership and China’s Xi Jinping yielded little, not even a joint statement https://t.co/JRlMHE2ZrQ

name: nytimes
text: In the race for the most powerful computers, Fugaku, a Japanese supercomputer, recently beat American and Chinese machines https://t.co/dNBmbnJaPF

name: nytimes
text:
Further lockdown measures have been announced in northwestern Germany, after a coronavirus outbreak at a meat-processing plant.
 
Latest updates: https://t.co/ZMbyjS6tBx

name: nytimes
text: German cadets are taught in unsparing detail about the shameful legacy of policing under the Nazis. It “changes you as a person and changes you as a police officer," one inspector said. The nation's approach may hold lessons for police reform everywhere. https://t.co/C029CJEao9

name: nytimes
text: There is a growing realization that K-pop fans’ efficient social-media tactics for fund-raising or making a song go viral can also be used for political activism https://t.co/JN98cjlNIW

name: nytimes
text: The payment app Square is holding back a share of the funds it collects for small businesses, adding to their peril at an already difficult time https://t.co/KWPYysEHG2

name: nytimes
text: A letter signed by the “The Curatorial Department” of the Guggenheim Museum was sent to the institution's leadership demanding changes to “an inequitable work environment that enables racism, white supremacy, and other discriminatory practices” https://t.co/GsARWObiWL

name: nytimes
text: The Morning briefing: Here's what you need to know to start your day https://t.co/V7omfK3MDJ

name: nytimes
text:
RT @kbennhold: "It changes you as a person and as a police officer."
Before Inspector Halweg graduated from the police academy, he met Holocaust survivors and visited a concentration camp. 
In Germany, confronting a shameful legacy is a core part of police training: https://t.co/sMikAuC4Du

name: nytimes
text: Singapore prime minister announced on Tuesday that the city-state would hold the first elections in Southeast Asia since the coronavirus pandemic began on July 10 https://t.co/9nqmYmdujP

name: nytimes
text: Today’s Senate primary in Kentucky has been transformed by the outcry over police brutality. What can the election tell us about the future of Democratic politics? Listen to today's episode of "The Daily." https://t.co/Nqjfzdv3Cg

name: nytimes
text: Even before players tested positive for the coronavirus during a tennis tour organized by Novak Djokovic, there was concern about the optics of full stadiums and partying players with so many still suffering worldwide https://t.co/nUb9hLGHD6

name: nytimes
text:
RT @luisferre: It’s Primary Day! 

There’s the presidential Democratic primary, as well as House races, and primaries in State Senate and Assembly. Queens will pick its borough president.

Here’s what you need to know to vote in New York today:

https://t.co/bKjKAJAD1w

name: nytimes
text: Some white Americans admitted that even the process of reflecting on racism underscored for them how little they grasp the everyday experience of being black in America https://t.co/EYiJnEY1ck

name: nytimes
text: Here's a rundown of the highlights worth watching from late-night TV https://t.co/jKvJWw5Aa1

name: nytimes
text: Breaking News: England will lift most lockdown restrictions on July 4, paving the way to open pubs and restaurants. The required social distance will be cut in half. https://t.co/sd8ywXZaAW

name: nytimes
text:
New York, Kentucky and Virginia are holding primary elections today. Results may be delayed because of the many voters casting absentee ballots.

Here’s what to watch for:
https://t.co/ApYWiuBfPf

name: nytimes
text: An American soldier confessed to sharing secret information with a satanic neo-Nazi-group in a plot to cause “the deaths of as many of his fellow service members as possible,” federal prosecutors said https://t.co/WOemLzwWDE

name: nytimes
text: France on Monday brought home 10 children of French jihadists who had been stuck in sprawling detention camps in northeastern Syria since at least the collapse of the Islamic State last year https://t.co/ltqTvtXW9b

name: nytimes
text:
Novak Djokovic said he tested positive for the coronavirus, the fourth player to do so after he organized a tournament in Croatia and Serbia.
https://t.co/mkCwWIajif

name: nytimes
text: The FDA is warning U.S. consumers to avoid 9 hand sanitizer products because, it said, they may contain methanol, a substance that can be toxic if absorbed through the skin or ingested https://t.co/rJRcSQFAbU

name: nytimes
text: RT @amyyqin: When I visited the Yulin Dog Meat Festival in 2015, I was struck by the # of Chinese animal activists who turned out. They have persisted ever since even as the space for activism has shrunk & thanks to the virus they recently notched a few victories. https://t.co/F7ME2uXjQX

name: nytimes
text: For years, animal rights activists in China have tried to persuade the government and the public to support banning the eating of dogs and cats. They scored few concrete wins. The coronavirus, which spread from a food market in China, changed everything. https://t.co/SlxJXvJMmi

name: nytimes
text: Scientists announced evidence that a volcanic eruption in the Aleutian Islands, 6,000 miles away from Italy, contributed to the demise of the Roman Republic. That eruption — and others before it and since — played a role in changing the course of history. https://t.co/7tPAMRRDF8

name: nytimes
text:
2 wallaroos and a red kangaroo were found dead in an outdoor exhibit of the San Francisco Zoo days before a young mountain lion was captured in the city
https://t.co/Dw9NauD6wF

name: nytimes
text:
A prestigious wine organization will stop its common use of “master” with a sommelier’s surname and will institute other changes to improve inclusivity in the wine industry. But black wine professionals don’t think the efforts are enough.
https://t.co/TfA8KEdzrI

name: nytimes
text:
“I’m suffocating,” Cédric Chouviat called out 7 times as officers in Paris put him in a chokehold in January, according to videos revealed this week. His death has reignited scrutiny of police chokeholds.
https://t.co/i76CpNplTI

name: nytimes
text:
The wildly popular trading card game “Magic: The Gathering” is pulling several playing cards with racist names and imagery, including one titled “Invoke Prejudice” whose image depicts figures in pointed hoods resembling those of the Ku Klux Klan
https://t.co/dz9eIaWXMG

name: nytimes
text:
In Opinion

Wesley Lowery writes, “The failure of the mainstream press to accurately cover black communities is intrinsically linked with its failure to employ, retain and listen to black people” https://t.co/D1GASbhGwf
